H0.text: A controlled single-variable laboratory test is the type of validation required for the hypothesis of an expanding universe before it was accepted as a significant part of scientific theory.

H1.text: Support through evidence from numerous observations is the type of validation required for the hypothesis of an expanding universe to be accepted as a significant part of scientific theory.

H2.text: Proposal of alternative explanations with predictive value is the type of validation required for the hypothesis of an expanding universe before it was accepted as a significant part of scientific theory.

H3.text: A full‑scale replication of each event in the proper sequence was required as the validation for the hypothesis of an expanding universe before it was accepted as a significant part of scientific theory.

A4.text: In 1922, Alexander Friedmann used the Einstein field equations to provide theoretical evidence that the universe is expanding.

A5.text: Supernova observations were used to determine that cosmic expansion is accelerating in the present epoch.

A6.text: In 1927, Georges Lemaître concluded that the universe might be expanding by noting the proportionality of the recessional velocity of distant bodies to their respective distances.

A7.text: In 1912, Vesto M. Slipher measured the first Doppler shift of a 'spiral nebula' and soon discovered that almost all such objects were receding from Earth.
